title: Thursday, 17th January 2019
bodyHTML:
11:12 am

11:15 am
BE11:16am

Jack Bogle, founder of Vanguard and creator of the world’s first index mutual fund, has died at the age of 89. He leaves an unassailable legacy as the pioneer and leading advocate of the $10tn index investment universe.

Born in New Jersey to a family stricken by the Great Depression, he became one of the greatest men in the history of investing by ripping asunder the “great man” image of supreme, cerebral stockpickers who could beat the market.

Soundbuy Sounding like a modern day Citizen Smith
BE11:16am

Which ties into this Wigglesworth big read about passives from late last year: https://www.ft.com...-9d01-cd4d49afbbe3

A. M. Morning all.
FATDAZ @excel not sure he did invent the idea of an index tracker I believe that was done by someone at the American stock exchange but what he certainly did was popularise their use
Finlay Morning all. I'd like to consult with you all on something where I know I'm right and don't intend to budge an inch. Please ignore that ticking bomb in the corner.
BE11:17am

Which references the pretty great argument from 2017 that passive investing is Marxism: https://ftalphavil...eactivegreatagain/

wayneJ Isn't what we saw in December the result of passives? Poor liquidity and falling active component makes markets sensitive to 'liquidity crashes'
Blank canvas BE, one of my New Year's resolutions was to be more judgemental - I suggest you do the same.
wayneJ @Finlay - are you running for office? Perhaps for #10? Have you been in a wheat field?
11:19 am
BE11:19am

Which ties back into the first Levine of 2019, which was (needless to say) brilliant: https://www.bloomb...where?srnd=opinion

Airborne Cigar @BE - Is your collection of irritations tagged, or just catalogued?
wayneJ Is there an event horizon where Bryce's 'ever growing collections of irritations' will become a Black Hole?
rusty Feels like the markets of late have become increasingly sensitive to vol changes. Twitchy sell fingers possibly reflecting underlying malaise with the state of the economy(s)?
BE11:20am

Okay, that's given you all something worth reading. Now to push on with the stuff you can safely ignore.

On the idea that "digital natives" (which means adults younger than 35, it seems) aren't watching telly.

Blackbag99 So they like Netflix. And there can only be 3-4 distribution channels
A. M. @WayneJ: that's what I had in mind, up to a point.
rusty In fairness, if the BBC turned off all broadcasting and was just iPlayer... I'm not sure I'd notice the difference.

Hang on, I can't quote the note itself so here's the summary I've just written of it for elsewhere.

A. M. @rusty: can the infrastructure handle such a thing?
Finlay @Blackbag - not even Netflix. YouTube is watched more in my experience
doeswalk What's telly?
wayneJ Er - I was trying to start an online video co in the 1990s. Why has it taken Merrills so long?
rusty @A.M. Yes, with the same model that Netflix et al use of colocating the content next to the last mile (e.g. there's probably a few racks of Netflix servers in your local Virgin Media data centre)
BE11:24am

Merrill Lynch downgraded ITV, Mediaset and ProSiebenSat.1 to “underperform” based on evidence that the shift to online video is accelerating. It forecast TV advertising spend to decline by 2 to 3 per cent by 2025 and argued that the terrestrial broadcasters in UK and Germany as the most vulnerable to the trend.

TV consumption is declining by 8 per cent year-on-year among adults younger than 35, twice to three times faster than average, said Merrill. By 2020 these “digital natives” will represent more than 50 per cent of labor force, up from around 35 per cent in 2015, so will be key targets for advertisers, it said. The cost of TV advertising aimed at this cohort has doubled or trebled in the past five years, whereas online video is now 30 to 40 per cent cheaper, the broker estimated.

The unsustainable inflation means the terrestrial broadcasters need to make big investments to recapture online space and, with content costs spiraling, operating margins are likely to compress by 500 basis points by 2025, Merrill forecast.

Its note also downgraded both Atresmedia and RTL to “underperform” and moved TF1 down to “neutral”.

wayneJ (Didn't Merrill parent BAC report last night - analyst note well timed to get attention just before bonus allocations?)
11:24 am
BE11:25am

All of which you've probably read quite a lot over the years, though if you're a Merrill client you have the option of reading 108 pages of it this morning.

rusty @wayne - true, though the rise of 4k is pushing sizes up by a large margin. @A.M. - I'm not sure about the costing for the colo racks, I was under the impression that Netflix does it for free, the ISP gains with lower upstream bandwidth costs/peering costs
BE11:27am

Overall, it's reassuring stuff for a jittery sector. Here's Goldman.

BE11:28am

Commentary on the US is also very solid, with management pleased with performance and now expecting a much reduced loss yoy in the region. Primark margin commentary is broadly unchanged versus the AGM stage (and therefore slightly ahead of initial plans), with strong stock management supporting improved margins. On Sugar, on balance commentary is more positive in our view: in-line with comments from Suedzucker last week, ABF is seeing “early signs of recovery in EU sugar prices”; and a reduction in the beet price paid to Spanish growers has now been agreed. Whilst China is, unfortunately, now expected to be loss making in the current year, this business is small relative to Europe. Commentary on the other divisions is broadly unchanged versus the FY 18 results/AGM stage. FY 19 group guidance for a broadly flat operating profit and EPS yoy is unchanged. Whilst the stock has rallied versus recent lows, this move has been below the sector bounce (ABF shares ytd +7% versus sector +11%), and we think this overall reassuring statement (particularly in light of more mixed recent news flow) should send the shares higher today.

FATDAZ @Rusty BofA ML (I believe it was) published a strategy note earlier in January in which they highlighted that US equities a under their coverage were increasingly sensitive to Macro factors of which Volatility was foremost
wayneJ @AM - network architecture - in the US peering points tend to be for profit. In Europe (eg LINX in London) tended to be not for profit.

Excel Developer #Algos On the subject of market gyrations, Matt Levine writes "Does that mean that the computers have developed emotions of their own?" No. It just means they're programs have bugs and unexpected side effects.

What does it all mean? All else equal, these 1Q results imply no material change to Bloomberg consensus FY19 PBT of £1,374mn and 136.3p EPS, +1% yoy.
Valuation: Our SOTP-based 12-month price target is 2500p. This assumes peer group valuation metrics for ABF’s food manufacturing earnings and values Primark using a 10-year DCF, driving the following EVs: Primark £11.4bn, Grocery £4.9bn, Agriculture £0.8bn, Ingredients £2.3bn, and Sugar £0.6bn.

BE11:32am

Boohoo is able to do this as about half of its manufacturing base is in Britain, with the rest in continental Europe, China and India. Screens around Boohoo’s headquarters, updated every 15 minutes, show which items are selling best so that buyers can reorder popular items as needed. On an average week, Boohoo can have as many as 500 new lines on its website.

Blackbag99 Algos have programming, you can pervert programming. If you think you understand its structure it is vulnerable.
wayneJ (BE showing his net neutrality by sending us all off on links to other news outlets :-) )
wayneJ In fact M&S went through about 2 decades of cutting off UK suppliers - management blissfully betting the whole co. on 'buyers' guessing next seasons' trends.
rusty @A.M. Yes, but can I provide a better experience for my content without running in to neutrality issues just by ensuing it's located closer to the consumer and thus reducing latency and contention
BE11:34am

...... and just-in-time manufacturing. There are a number of important questions to ask about Boohoo as an investment case -- see yesterday's session -- but you have to admire the slickness of its business model.

wayneJ Some advice required - we have BT superfast broadband - but it enters our house on copper wires via a telegraph pole which brings it across the road (there are ducts on the other side). We keep on having blackouts and despite paying for 70Mbps we get only 20 - 30 Mbps and sometimes 2mbps and often zero. What do we do. At the moment the only solution is to reset the homehub (or new Netgear modem we are testing) and hope for the best

Also note that the shares have bounced back a fair bit from the FY warning, suggesting the buyside were already higher up the 2019 guidance range than the sellside. That range doesn't change today.

BE11:38am

Here's Goldman.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

We were encouraged by Sage’s 1Q-FY19 trading update with an organic revenue growth of +7.6%, albeit against relatively easier comp. We believe the quality of growth was good with an organic recurring revenue growth of 10.5% in 1Q, driven by subscription growth at 27.7%, a modest acceleration vs prior quarters, suggesting the cloud transition is on track. By geography, the organic growth was broad based across geographies with continued strength in North America (10.4% organic growth) and continued recovery in France (5.8% organic growth) and UK (5.9% organic growth), which should be seen as reassuring in our view. We note that given an unchanged FY19 guidance of c.5%-7% organic growth, organic growth of +7.6% slightly lowers the bar for the remainder of FY19 (Organic growth of 7.6%+ in 1Q implies 9MFY19 growth of 4.7%-7.1% vs FY19 guidance of 5.4%-7.2%). Having said that we note that the comps get tougher in 2HFY19 (7.3% organic growth in 2HFY18).

BE11:38am

And Morgan Stanley.

FATDAZ @WayneJ do you live in area that was cabled by Virgin and predecessors?
BE11:39am

Sage's 1Q update reflected an unexpectedly strong start to FY19 with group organic revenues up 7.6% to £465m - heading into the first quarter, we had expected growth around 6.4% (6.2% for 1H) with street at 5.7% for 1H as a whole. Within this, Sage noted that recurring revenues were up 10.5% organically, a significant acceleration over the mid-6% 4Q18 run-rate, while SSRS declined 5.8%. Performance was strong across geographies, with North America +10.4% (helped by Intacct), a sharp recovery in the UK (+5.9%) following low single digit growth in FY18, and continued growth in France (+5.8%). While sell-side expectations reduced sharply following FY18 results (from 6.9% growth for FY19 to 5.7%), we think buy side expectations will have been higher given clear share price outperformance over the last 2 months and a NTM P/E re-rating back towards 1 s.d. above its long term average. Sage reiterated its full year guidance for organic recurring revenue growth of 8-9%, flat to down mid single digits organic revenue growth for SSRS and processing (implying 5- 7% group org growth), and an underlying operating margin of 23% to 25%. We anticipate consensus is likely to move from 5.7% organic growth for the FY above the mid-point of the implied 5-7% FY guide, and see the stock up towards mid single digits today.

With SocGen also setting the div at the minimum of E2.2, encouraging takeup of the scrip. Here's RBC.

BE11:43am

Assuming a 60% take-up of the dividend in shares at a 10% discount, we calculate a 5% EPS dilution, but this depends on the take-up in shares. A 100% take-up in shares at 10% discount would lead to an 8% dilution.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

The CET 1 ratio is expected at 11.4-11.6% including 26bp for disposals and 26bp the stock dividend (assuming 50% share take-up). This would suggest it came out at 10.9% to 11.2%, down from 11.2% at the end of Q3.

rusty @rw42 - I don't know quite enough about the numbers in play for ISP level bandwidth to have a good answer. I'm approaching more from the strategic perspective than the nut and bolts economic one

And the bottom line:

rw42 @WayneJ https://www.homeandbusiness.openreach.co.uk/fibre-broadband/when-can-i-get-fibre
BE11:44am

The 2018 stock dividend will have the largest impact on our estimates. The issue is that it now makes a stock option more likely in the next
years. Consensus pre results forecasted a 2020 CET 1 ratio of 11.9% vs the 12% target. The FY 2018 stock dividend (24bp on 50% take-up as
per SG comments) should bring the estimate closer to 12%.
The impact of weaker Q4 performance in GM on our estimates going forward depends on the development of the IB environment. A 10%
change in our Global Markets revenues in 2020 takes 3% off our group revenues.

wayneJ (BE - if people had not been soooo unkind to Avanti I could have tried them as a viable alternative ---- perhaps funded by the profits on my short position there!)

And sector:

BE11:44am

The weaker Global Markets trends should have an impact on BNP’s performance too where we forecast currently an 8% decline in GM
revenues. However, we see a stock dividend as less likely but assume a decline in the absolute DPS in 2018 vs 2017. We see less of a readthrough
to Casa given the stronger capital ratio. For the EU IBs, we believe expectations have been largely rebased post this week's US banks
results.

BE11:59am

SSP’s momentum continues with another quarter of solid LFL sales growth combined with better than expected contract wins. North American remains particularly impressive with several wins across secondary international airports. Protests in France and several redevelopments could weigh on Continental Europe LFL growth in 1H but FY19 guidance remains 2.0-3.0% and net contract gains should now be 'a little ahead' of the previously guided 3.0%. The fundamentals for global travel and convenience continue to be strong and SSP is taking share. The stock trades on 10.9x EV/EBITDA and 23.5x PE for CY19E and offers double digit earnings growth, now augmented by increased prospects of on-going cash returns to shareholders. Our DCF suggests a value of 863p with our TP set at c15% discount to this. BUY

SSP Group PLC (SSPG:LSE): Last: 682.80, up 3.5 (+0.52%), High: 691.30, Low: 681.70, Volume: 132.56k

11:59 am
BE11:59am

The fundamentals for global travel and convenience continue with SSP taking share. The stock is trading on CY19E EV/EBITDA of 10.9x and PE of 23.5x based on current FY19E forecasts for EBITDA of £324.7m and adj EPS of 28p, and offers strong double digit earnings growth, now augmented by increased prospects of on-going cash returns to shareholders (net debt/EBITDA 1.1x). Our DCF suggests a valuation of 863p and our target is set at a 15% discount to this.

Excel Developer Does anyone trade bonds here? 10Y Gilt yielded 1.7 in Oct but now 1.3 If I had a zero coupon bond then the price went from 84.5 to 87.8, a 4% gain or ~16% annualised.
